items.title: Clima, dalla COP30 piccole vittorie che lasciano grandi vuoti
items.description:
A Belém, i paesi non hanno trovato un accordo sulle roadmap per abbandonare i combustibili fossili e fermare la deforestazione
The post Clima, dalla C
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie A Belém, i paesi non hanno trovato un accordo sulle roadmap per abbandonare i combustibili fossili e porre fine alla deforestazione nel testo ufficiale, ma la Presidenza le ha annunciate come iniziative che un gruppo di paesi comincerà a perseguire. I paesi riuniti alla COP30 hanno approvato una serie di azioni modeste, tra cui la decisione di attuare un meccanismo di transizione equo. Inoltre, al di fuori dei testi negoziati formalmente approvati, il Brasile in quanto presidenza della COP guiderà una sede di dibattito internazionale sulle tabelle di marcia per l’abbandono dei combustibili fossili e la fine della deforestazione in base alle indicazioni della comunità scientifica. Eppure, visto che questo è stato il primo vertice sul clima dopo che il mondo ha registrato un intero anno con temperature superiori a 1,5 °C – un duro promemoria dell’urgenza che dobbiamo affrontare – questi progressi sono insufficienti per promuovere l’azione urgente e trasformativa necessaria per evitare impatti climatici devastanti e proteggere le persone e la natura. Gli sforzi della presidenza non sono bastati Nonostante gli sforzi della presidenza brasiliana e il sostegno di almeno 86 paesi, i negoziatori non sono riusciti a concordare alcun riferimento diretto alla transizione dai combustibili fossili nei testi formali. Allo stesso modo, mentre più di 90 paesi hanno sostenuto un piano di attuazione per arrestare e invertire la deforestazione entro il 2030, a Belém è mancata una più ampia volontà politica per garantire questo obiettivo, nonostante la foresta amazzonica facesse da sfondo al vertice. In risposta, la presidenza della COP ha annunciato che il Brasile guiderà le discussioni internazionali sulle tabelle di marcia come iniziative presidenziali -la presidenza brasiliana durerà sino alla prossima COP- iniziative che saranno presentate alla COP31 il prossimo anno. Un risultato importante: il meccanismo di transizione equo Un risultato importante della COP è la decisione di istituire un meccanismo di transizione equo per promuovere la cooperazione internazionale. Il preambolo della COP menziona anche le popolazioni indigene, le comunità locali e gli afro-discendenti, nonché gli oceani, le foreste e la scienza. “Grandi promesse non tradotte in azioni significative” Mariagrazia Midulla, responsabile clima ed energia del WWF Italia, ha dichiarato: “Al termine della COP30, la realtà è chiara: titoli altisonanti e grandi promesse non si sono tradotti in azioni significative. La cosiddetta ‘COP della verità’ non ha fornito né una tabella di marcia né soluzioni concrete per le sfide urgenti che dobbiamo affrontare. Il documento finale è debole e privo di sostanza a causa dei giochi delle forze contrarie all’ambizione climatica e alla sua attuazione. La crisi climatica è provocata principalmente da due fattori, i combustibili fossili, responsabili di oltre il 75% delle emissioni climalteranti, e la deforestazione: sono proprio i due elementi che mancano dal documento finale. Segno che la lentezza non è provocata dai trattati e dalle sedi multilaterali, ma la mancanza di volontà politica da parte dei paesi e la subalternità di molti alle manovre delle lobby fossili. Eppure, l’energia e l’impegno dimostrati da così tante persone nella società civile, nella scienza e nelle comunità in prima linea ci ricordano che un vero cambiamento è ancora possibile. Non possiamo permetterci altri gesti vuoti. Il mondo ha bisogno di azioni concrete e attuabili, ora più che mai. Qualunque cosa di meno mina le persone, la natura e le generazioni future”. “Il multilateralismo è vivo” Bernardo Tarantino, specialista Affari Europei e Internazionali, presente a Belem, ha dichiarato:  “ “Il multilateralismo è vivo — ed è una buona notizia. Ma fatica a compiere passi avanti sulle azioni cruciali per ridurre le emissioni e arrestare il degrado delle foreste. Mentre i Paesi dell’America Latina — Colombia e Brasile in particolare — e i piccoli Stati insulari, minacciati nella loro stessa sopravvivenza dal cambiamento climatico, spingono per misure concrete con scadenze certe, altri gruppi di Paesi legati all’economia fossile si oppongono a qualsiasi avanzamento. L’Unione europea ha infine sostenuto con forza una roadmap per il ‘transitioning away’ dai combustibili fossili, ma la sua posizione è stata inizialmente rallentata da alcune ambiguità, tra cui quelle dell’Italia. Spiace constatare che il nostro Paese non sia in prima fila nel portare avanti l’agenda globale per la riduzione delle emissioni e l’uscita dall’economia fossile. Ma il consenso per una vera transizione globale è forte e riemergerà nelle prossime COP”.

items.title: Pensioni, l’INPS dice addio a 2 opzioni e perdi soldi: cosa cambierà nei prossimi mesi
items.description:
Con l’avvicinarsi del 2026, il sistema pensionistico italiano si prepara a importanti novità che riguardano l’età pensionabile. Questi
L'articolo Pens
items.body:
Sostenibilità
                             
                                                
                                        Pensioni, l’INPS dice addio a 2 opzioni e perdi soldi: cosa cambierà nei prossimi mesi

Roberto Arciola

Novembre 24, 2025

Pensione anticipata: la sorpresa della Quota 100 ancora valida(www.greenstyle.it)

Con l’avvicinarsi del 2026, il sistema pensionistico italiano si prepara a importanti novità che riguardano l’età pensionabile.

Questi cambiamenti derivano principalmente dal meccanismo di adeguamento automatico all’aspettativa di vita, che continuerà a spostare sempre più avanti l’età di uscita dal lavoro.
Dal 2027 scatterà un aumento di un mese nell’età per la pensione di vecchiaia, che passerà da 67 anni a 67 anni e un mese. L’anno successivo, nel 2028, l’età richiesta salirà ulteriormente a 67 anni e tre mesi. Per quanto riguarda la pensione anticipata, i requisiti contributivi si incrementeranno: per gli uomini si passerà da 42 anni e 10 mesi a 42 anni e 11 mesi nel 2027, e a 43 anni e un mese dal 2028; per le donne da 41 anni e 10 mesi a 41 anni e 11 mesi nel 2027, salendo a 42 anni e un mese nel 2028.
Questi adeguamenti sono stati parzialmente mitigati dalla legge di bilancio 2026, che ha previsto un rallentamento nell’aumento legato alla speranza di vita, limitando l’incremento a un mese nel 2027 e a due mesi nel 2028, anziché i tre mesi previsti dal meccanismo originario.
Un’importante esclusione riguarda i lavoratori impiegati in attività usuranti e gravose, per i quali l’aumento dei requisiti pensionistici sarà congelato fino al 2028. Questo riguarda circa il 2% dei nuovi pensionati, una platea ristretta ma significativa per il sistema previdenziale.
Stop a Quota 103 e Opzione Donna, proroga per l’Ape Sociale
La bozza della legge di bilancio 2026 conferma la fine di due misure temporanee introdotte negli ultimi anni per favorire pensionamenti anticipati: Quota 103 e Opzione Donna non saranno infatti rinnovate.
Quota 103, nata come misura sperimentale per consentire il pensionamento anticipato con 62 anni di età e 41 anni di contributi, prevede il ricalcolo contributivo dell’assegno, con una significativa riduzione dell’importo rispetto al calcolo tradizionale. Questa misura ha registrato un utilizzo limitato e sarà quindi abbandonata.
Parallelamente, la misura di pensionamento anticipato dedicata alle donne, Opzione Donna, che richiede almeno 61 anni di età e 35 anni di contributi con ricalcolo contributivo, non verrà prorogata. Introdotta nel 2004 per riconoscere le difficoltà specifiche delle lavoratrici, l’Opzione Donna ha subito diverse modifiche nel tempo, restringendo progressivamente la platea delle beneficiarie e mantenendo il vincolo del calcolo contributivo, spesso penalizzante.
Resta invece attiva e prorogata per un ulteriore anno l’Ape Sociale, uno strumento rivolto ai lavoratori con almeno 63 anni e 5 mesi di età e 30 anni di contributi, che si trovano in condizioni di difficoltà quali disoccupazione, invalidità, attività gravose o ruolo di caregiver. Questa misura continua ad essere un importante scivolo pensionistico per categorie particolarmente vulnerabili.
Pensione anticipata flessibile e novità normative- Greenstyle.it
Fra le novità del sistema previdenziale per il biennio 2024-2025 si conferma la possibilità della pensione anticipata flessibile, che consente ai lavoratori dipendenti e autonomi di andare in pensione con almeno 62 anni di età e 41 anni di contributi, a condizione di cessare il rapporto di lavoro.
Il trattamento pensionistico viene liquidato secondo il sistema contributivo e prevede finestre di attesa variabili: 7 mesi per i lavoratori privati e 9 mesi per i dipendenti pubblici, con decorrenze particolari per comparti come scuola e AFAM. È importante sottolineare che la pensione anticipata flessibile non è cumulabile con i redditi da lavoro, fatta eccezione per redditi da lavoro autonomo occasionale entro il limite annuo di 5.000 euro lordi.
La domanda per questa prestazione può essere presentata online all’INPS, tramite Contact Center o enti di patronato.
Il futuro delle pensioni: nuove ipotesi e proposte in discussione
Nel contesto delle riforme pensionistiche, si valuta ancora la possibilità di bloccare o rallentare ulteriormente l’aumento automatico dell’età pensionabile, soprattutto per alcune categorie di lavoratori. Le ipotesi allo studio prevedono un congelamento dell’incremento per il biennio 2027-2028 o l’introduzione di “finestre” aggiuntive, cioè periodi di attesa supplementari di uno o due mesi per la decorrenza della pensione.
Il dibattito politico e sindacale resta acceso, con la Lega che spinge per un blocco totale dell’aumento per tutti, mentre il Ministero dell’Economia mantiene una posizione più prudente, considerando la sostenibilità finanziaria del sistema e l’andamento demografico.

Continue Reading

On January 27, 2025, clumps of solidified vegetable oil were found along a 25 km stretch of coastline on Finland’s Hanko Peninsula. While not toxic, the substance posed risks to wildlife. Suspecting it came from a passing vessel’s cargo tank wash, Finnish authorities launched an investigation,…

The COSNORTH-SEMAR DSS is a decision-support system developed to enhance maritime surveillance and law enforcement along Spain’s northern coast. Created in collaboration with the Guardia Civil, it combines environmental data, vessel tracking, and predictive modeling in a user-friendly platform…

Planning a sailing route based on weather used to be hard and needed expert skills. Many sailors didn’t use it because it was too complicated. SailRouting changes that by offering an easy online tool that shows weather-based routes in just a few clicks — no setup needed.

With SailRouting…

This study examines the environmental conditions near the Motagua River mouth in the Caribbean Sea, focusing on mangrove resilience, plastic pollution, and water turbidity. Photosynthesis data reveals magrove strong resistance with high absorption values in northern and southern regions, though…

❄️ In the N Hemisphere, reduced winter sunlight at high latitudes leads to colder temps & the formation of ice along the E coast of 🇬🇱 Greenland.🛰 #CopernicusEU Sentinel-2 #ImageOfTheDay shows the region illuminated by the low sun, which creates typical elongated shadows. pic.twitter.com/0AOfZQeNGw

— Copernicus EU (@CopernicusEU) November 23, 2025

🔥 A wildfire swept through nearly 3,000 hectares of alpine ecosystem in the Tongariro National Park, NZ 🇳🇿 on 8 Nov.🛰 This #ImageOfTheDay by one of the #CopernicusEU Sentinel-2 satellites (15 Nov) 2025, shows a clear burn scar in red tones.🔗 https://t.co/zYwH14dJvt pic.twitter.com/ST46uY6upw

— Copernicus EU (@CopernicusEU) November 22, 2025

🌧️ Intense flooding and a devastating landslide struck Friuli Venezia Giulia in N Italy 🇮🇹 following prolonged, intense rainfall on 18 Nov. 🛰️ This #CopernicusEU Sentinel-2 #ImageOfTheDay reveals the heavy sediment discharge into the Gulf of Trieste.🔗 https://t.co/0yz1wG9Sl9 pic.twitter.com/TN568M5yyK

— Copernicus EU (@CopernicusEU) November 21, 2025

items.title: Fingerprints of stratospheric particle transport and fallout
Future Population Exposure to Extreme Precipitation Slows Down in China’s Urban Agglomerations Despite Global Warming
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 24 November 2025

Future Population Exposure to Extreme Precipitation Slows Down in China’s Urban Agglomerations Despite Global Warming
                    Lu Tang1 na1, Miaoni Gao2 na1, Jing Yang1, Yue Zheng3 & …Yaochi Su4 Show authors

npj Urban Sustainability

volume 5, Article number: 95 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change impactsProjection and prediction

AbstractGlobal warming intensifies regional extreme precipitation, escalating fatalities. However, the risk trend to regional populations from heavy rainfall remains uncertain due to declining populations in some areas. Here, we investigate both the frequency of extreme precipitation (EPF) and the associated population exposure (EP-PE) across four major urban agglomerations (UAs) in China for the historical record and future scenarios. Both EPF and EP-PE exhibit upward trends in most UAs over three decades, though their spatial high-value patterns diverge due to heterogeneous population distribution. Using an innovative precipitation percentile mapping method applied to the NEX-GDDP-CMIP6 dataset, we find that EPF is expected to increase across all emission scenarios, but EP-PE will initially rise before decelerating, with regional variations in timing of turning points. Notably, under low greenhouse gas emission scenarios, EP-PE in the Yangtze River Delta and Chengdu-Chongqing UAs is projected to decline by the end of the century. These findings underscore the role of urban demographic changes in shaping climate risks and highlight the need for integrated sustainable strategies.

IntroductionAccumulating evidence reveals climate change may jeopardize 72 targets under 16 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)1, while potentially intensifying extreme precipitation2. Since the mid-20th century, these events have become among the most widespread meteorological disasters, affecting approximately 10% of the global population3. Rapid urban expansion has led to an increase in impervious surfaces, reducing water infiltration and amplifying runoff, thereby intensifying the risks associated with urban precipitation anomalies4,5. At the same time, this has been accompanied by an escalating strain on drainage systems, which can even have adverse effects on groundwater security, further posing serious threats to public health, urban operations, and infrastructure6,7,8,9. By 2050, over 70% of the global population is projected to reside in urban areas10. As the most advanced spatial organization of cities, urban agglomerations (UAs) play a critical role, and understanding changes in extreme precipitation and their impacts on exposed populations in UAs is essential for designing climate-adaptive governance frameworks and disaster mitigation strategies11.Significant increases in extreme precipitation are observed in China, a highly climate-vulnerable country, causing substantial losses and casualties12. For instance, on July 20, 2021, Zhengzhou in China suffered severe flooding from extreme precipitation, affecting 14.78 million people and resulting in 398 deaths and disappearances. Since 1961, while extreme precipitation trends have varied regionally, areas experiencing increases have generally dominated13. Extreme precipitation events will become more severe and frequent, with the number of heavy precipitation days expected to increase by 2 to 3 times by the end of the century14. Urbanization critically amplifies extreme precipitation intensity in urban zones15,16 especially in larger and more densely populated cities, where the intensified urban heat island effect may further exacerbate the impacts of extreme rainfall17,18. However, despite future population growth being anticipated to concentrate in UAs, the extreme precipitation frequency (EPF) and risks in these areas remain unclear.Phase 6 of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6) offers valuable opportunities for projecting extreme precipitation and assessing associated risks, improving the accuracy of extreme event simulations19,20, often resulting in regional overestimations or underestimations21. To address these challenges, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) developed the NASA Earth Exchange Global Daily Downscaled Projections (NEX-GDDP) dataset, which integrates bias-corrected spatial disaggregation based on CMIP6 (NEX-GDDP-CMIP6)22. This dataset enhances regional climate information relative to CMIP6, reducing biases and root mean square error while preserving spatial correlations and constraining uncertainties in extreme precipitation simulations23,24. Nevertheless, it still struggles to improve the simulation of annual extreme precipitation days25. Although bias correction methods are widely employed, they risk distorting climate change signals or misrepresenting extreme values26,27. Thus, when using absolute thresholds, which can more intuitively display extreme precipitation risks, the performance of NEX-GDDP-CMIP6 in reproducing extreme precipitation and whether we can detect extreme precipitation in model data more effectively still require further investigation.Exposure plays a crucial role in determining disaster risk and its impacts. Studies show that from 1960 to 201428, the population exposed to extreme precipitation (EP-PE) in China has increased significantly and is projected to continue rising until the end of this century—even under future scenarios of national population decline, which fails to offset the intensified impacts driven by increasing extreme precipitation, particularly under high greenhouse gas (GHG) emission scenarios29,30. The Pearl River Delta (PRD), the Yangtze River Delta (YRD), Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH), and Chengdu–Chongqing (CC) are China’s national-level UAs, which encompassed merely 7.6% of national territory yet housed 32.8% of the population in 202031. Over the past two decades, these regions have dominated national rankings in urban expansion, and future urbanization is expected to further drive population migration toward these eastern UAs32,33, but population distribution remains uncertain, due to evolving socio-economic factors, regional development strategies, and fertility policy changes (e.g., the transition from Two-Child to Three-Child policies in China)34,35,36. While extensive research has examined EP-PE at national, regional, and basin scales37,38,39, urban agglomerations remain underexplored, despite their strategic importance to China’s national development. Most existing studies either focus on a single UA or rely on static population data40. Therefore, under the dual impact of climate change and dynamic population changes, the future EP–PE in China’s UAs remains uncertain.Population exposure is essential for assessing the risks of extreme precipitation events. However, changes in EP-PE across UAs, key areas for population mobility in China’s rapidly urbanizing regions, remain unclear. We propose an innovative statistical correction method named precipitation percentile mapping (PPM) and optimally select model outputs. By systematically integrating the combined effects of climate change and population dynamics, we perform a comprehensive analysis of both observed and projected changes in extreme precipitation and EP-PE across China’s four national-level UAs. Our goal is to address the following research questions:1. What are the characteristics of EPF and EP-PE in China’s four national-level UAs from 1990 to 2020, and how have they changed?2. How will the future changes in population and EPF synergistically shape EP–PE in these four major UAs during the 21st century?ResultsIn densely populated areas, the exposure risk of extreme precipitation is likely to be more severe, making it essential to pinpoint regions with high levels of human activity. Based on the spatial distribution of nighttime light and population in 2020 (Fig. 1), this study identifies the four major UAs across central and eastern China—PRD, YRD, BTH, and CC—as areas of significant population and economic concentration.Fig. 1: Population and activity distribution across central and eastern China.a, b The spatial distribution of nighttime light and population in 2020, respectively. c The trends in total population and population density across the four UAs from 1990 to 2020. Stars in c denote significance as determined by the Mann–Kendall test (p < 0.05).Full size imageSpatial disparities in EPF and EP–PE hotspotsThe spatial distribution of high EP–PE regions does not fully overlap with areas most affected by extreme precipitation trends over the past three decades (Fig. 2a–d). EPF declines from the moist southeastern coastal areas towards the northwest, with the highest frequencies observed in the PRD, followed by the YRD and CC, while the BTH experiences the lowest frequency. Influenced by the EPF, the ranking of EP–PE in these four regions is consistent with the frequency. Nevertheless, in terms of spatial distribution, the areas of high population exposure in the four UAs contrast with those of frequent extreme precipitation events. For instance, in the YRD, extreme precipitation is concentrated in the western part of the region, particularly in Anhui Province. Yet, due to the combined impact of EPF and population density, areas with the highest risk for population exposure shift eastward, with the most affected regions found in the densely populated cities of Shanghai, southern Jiangsu, and Hangzhou. Similarly, in BTH and CC, the most significant EP–PE is found in the capital cities, Beijing and Chengdu, while in the PRD, the highest population exposure is primarily concentrated around the Pearl River Estuary, diverging from the EPF distribution.Fig. 2: Climatological distribution of EPF and EP–PE in the four major UAs of China.Spatial distribution of a EPF and b EP–PE from 1990 to 2020, and c, d their corresponding regional averages based on CN05.1.Full size imageAs depicted in Fig. 3a– d, the upward trends of EPF and EP–PE display pronounced regional disparities across the four UAs as well. Since the acceleration of global warming in 1990, approximately 15% of the areas in the PRD, YRD, and CC have experienced more extreme precipitation severely. Notably, driven by the interplay of population growth and escalating precipitation extremes, the area of regions experiencing a marked surge in EP–PE has expanded substantially. The PRD exhibits the most dramatic escalation, with over 70% of its area experiencing a sharp rise in exposure, which is 4.4 times greater than the spatial coverage of heightened EPF. In the rapidly growing populations of BTH and YRD (Fig. 1c), the growth rate of EP–PE has outpaced EPF by factors of 4 and 2.8 times, respectively, underscoring the magnified role of demographic shifts in amplifying exposure risks.Fig. 3: Observed changes in EPF and EP–PE across four UAs.The left and right panels show EPF and EP–PE, respectively. a, b The spatial distribution of the trends during 1990–2020, while c, d the percentage of areas exhibiting increasing (pink) and decreasing (blue) trends. Shaded areas in a–d indicate regions where the trends are statistically significant at the 95% confidence level.Full size imageOptimization of NEX–GDDP–CMIP6 simulationsTo make more reasonable estimates of extreme precipitation in major UAs in the future, this study evaluates the performance of the NEX–GDDP–CMIP6 models in reproducing extreme precipitation during the reference period. Our analysis demonstrates that the absolute 50 mm threshold better captures actual disaster impacts than relative thresholds (Supplementary Fig. 1), and is therefore maintained for future projections. As shown in Fig. 4a, despite downscaling and bias correction, when using a threshold of daily precipitation exceeding 50 mm to identify extreme precipitation, the multi-model ensemble (MME) from NEX–GDDP–CMIP6 significantly underestimates the EPF in China’s four major UAs. Specifically, in the southern PRD, the underestimation exceeds 6 times/year, while in the southwestern part of the YRD, the underestimation ranges from 2 to 6 times/year. In the BTH and CC UAs, the NEX-GDDP-CMIP6 models essentially fail to capture extreme precipitation.Fig. 4: Model evaluation and bias correction in the annual average EPF.Comparison of historical simulations and observations during 1995–2014, with historical simulations divided into two categories: a the original MME of 27 NEX–GDDP–CMIP6 models, and b the PPM bias-corrected MME of the top ten optimal-performing models.Full size imageTo refine the model simulations, this study applies the PPM bias correction approach, a variant of quantile mapping (QM). Unlike traditional QM method that adjusts the simulated precipitation values directly, PPM modifies only the threshold for identifying extreme precipitation, thus preserving the physical consistency and climate change signals inherent in the original model outputs. While achieving comparable correction performance to QM, PPM offers significantly improved computational efficiency and avoids disrupting inter-variable relationships (Supplementary Fig. 2). For each grid point in the observations, the percentile of precipitation amount corresponding to a local daily accumulated precipitation of 50 mm was determined. This percentile was then applied to each NEX–GDDP–CMIP6 model simulation to derive an absolute threshold. To ensure a consistent standard for future projections, the average of the absolute thresholds calculated from all models was ultimately used as the threshold for identifying extreme precipitation. Additionally, to improve the simulation results, an optimal-performing multi-model ensemble (op-MME) was selected, consisting of the top ten models based on comprehensive performance rankings across various aspects (Supplementary Fig. 3). After the correction, the bias of op-MME for extreme precipitation was significantly reduced, decreasing to within 0.5 times/year across all UAs (Fig. 4). In most regions, the bias ranges between −0.1 and 0.1 times/year, with only a small portion of areas in the eastern PRD and the northwestern YRD showing a slight overestimation of frequency by 0.3 to 0.5 times per year. In the BTH and CC regions, the bias also falls within the range of 0.1 to 0.3 times per year. The mean bias across the four UAs has shown a significant reduction, particularly in areas with originally high precipitation. The biases in the PRD, YRD, BTH, and CC regions decreased by 4.21, 1.86, 0.58, and 1.56 times per year, respectively.Future changes in EPF and EP-PEFigure 5a shows that EPF is projected to increase significantly across all four UAs in the 21st century based on the MME from ten optimal-performing NEX–GDDP–CMIP6 models. Especially when compared to the historical baseline (1995–2014), EPF by the end of the 21st century in the PRD, YRD, BTH, and CC is projected to increase by 47.7% (−12.9 to 110.5%) ~ 79.9% (20.7–205.6%), 71.1% (33.9–94.2%) ~135.0% (90.8–229.5%), 55.0% (−21.5 to 151.5%) ~124.7% (4.8–242.9%), and 39.8% (−15.1 to 137.4%) ~98.0% (−17.4 to 223.6%), respectively, although the magnitude of increase varies among different regions. Among all UAs, the increase in EPF is the most pronounced in the YRD. The increase in future near-term EPF is projected to reach 25.6% (−9.1 to 50.4%) ~35.9% (−7.9 to 50.8%), 44.4% (27.0–79.0%) ~52.3% (30.0–90.6%), 35.8% (−0.6 to 85.5%) ~38.6% (−11.0 to 80.1%) and 12.6% (−33.0 to 48.0%) ~22.1% (0.7–64.0%) under different shared socioeconomic pathways (SSPs). However, the increase in EPF under SSP1–2.6 pathway in the YRD, BTH, and CC regions exceeds that under the other two higher-emission pathways. This suggests that even under the stringent GHG emission requirements, EPF will not show a significant reduction in the short term.Fig. 5: Future changes in EPF across the four UAs.a The time series from the historical baseline period to the end of the 21st century under different SSPs, using op-MME. b The percentage changes for near-term, mid-term, and long-term futures compared to the historical baseline period. The shaded areas in a indicate the projection uncertainty characterized by inter-quartile ensemble spread, and solid lines represent the ensemble mean. Point and solid lines in b represent the ensemble average and median, respectively, and stars denote agreement among at least 2/3 of the models on the sign of change.Full size imageDespite rising EPF across the four major UAs, exposure peaks around the mid-21st century in most scenarios due to the projected decline in China’s population, rather than continuous growth (Figs. 6a, 7). In particular, in the PRD and BTH, substantial population growth is expected to cause the increase in EP–PE to surpass that of EPF. Compared to the historical baseline, the increases in EP–PE across PRD, YRD, BTH, and CC in the mid-term future are approximately 139.7% (52.9–190.5%) ~149.4% (76.9–222.7%), 46.2% (13.0–77.4%) ~59.2% (29.2–84.2%), 67.8% (−5.9 to 144.0%) ~78.4% (11.7–157.7%), and 11.0% (−46.3 to 67.3%) ~14.0% (−37.2 to 72.3%) under different SSPs, respectively. Subsequently, EP–PE in the four UAs is expected to decrease. Specifically, the increase in EP–PE in the PRD and BTH is projected to diminish, while in the YRD and CC, the EP–PE is even expected to decrease compared to the baseline. By the end of the 21st century, the change in EP–PE in the YRD and CC is projected to decline to −8.8% (−28.8 to 4.0%) and −29.3% (−64.7 to 30.5%), respectively.Fig. 6: Future changes in EP-PE across the four UAs.Similar to Fig. 5, but depicting the a time series of future EP-PE and b percentage changes over three epochs.Full size imageFig. 7: Future population changes in the four major UAs.a The time series of changes from 2020 to 2100, along with b the annual average population in three phases under different SSPs.Full size imageOur comparative analysis of emission pathways (based on the differences in ensemble means across pathways) reveals that lower GHG trajectories significantly reduce both EPF and population exposure risks across the four UAs relative to high-emission scenarios, with these mitigation benefits becoming particularly substantial by the end of the 21st century. In the long-term future, effective emissions reductions could result in decreases of 25.7% (−19.4 to 97.0%)/32.2% (−12.5 to 95.1%), 64.0% (27.8–141.7%)/47.7% (9.8–106.8%), 70.0% (−3.1 to 166.4%)/48.7% (−26.0 to 145.0%), and 58.2% (−8.6 to 140.3%)/45.8% (−6.6 to 105.9%) in EPF across PRD, YRD, BTH, and CC under the SSP1–2.6/SSP2–4.5 scenarios, respectively. Correspondingly, this would result in reductions of 31.5% (−28.8 to 116.1%)/22.7% (−37.2 to 84.2%), 39.0% (14.9–83.7%)/14.3% (−7.7 to 45.1%), 55.7% (−3.5 to 133.2%)/12.7% (−52.3 to 91.2%) and 29.5% (−4.1 to 127.4%)/8.5% (−12.9 to 71.1%) in EP–PE. Therefore, it is both beneficial and essential to limit future emissions to mitigate the occurrence of extreme weather events.DiscussionThis study investigates the future changes in EPF and EP-PE in China’s four major UAs throughout the 21st century, utilizing both observational data and optimal-performing NEX–GDDP–CMIP6 models. During the period 1990-2020, as global warming intensified, regions with high EPF and EP–PE values exhibited significant spatial disparities and escalating impacts. Notably, PRD experienced over 70% growth in EP-PE. The impact of population growth on exacerbating EP–PE is especially pronounced, with the growth rate of EP–PE in BTH and YRD substantially outpacing that of EPF. Based on PPM correction and model optimization, future projections of EPF and EP–PE for the four national-level UAs are conducted. Projections indicate that EPF will increase significantly across all four UAs, particularly in the YRD region, with variations depending on geographic location and emission scenarios. However, due to the combined effect of population, a substantial increase in EP–PE over the next 40 years is deemed nearly inevitable. Beyond this period, a gradual deceleration in EP–PE growth is anticipated. By the century’s end, EP–PE in YRD and CC is projected to decline, even dropping below baseline levels under the SSP1–2.6 pathway. These findings underscore that even in densely populated UAs, the synergistic effects of rapid population decline and GHG emission reductions post-mid-century can effectively mitigate EP–PE. It is important to note that the PPM method used in this study has certain limitations. Our analysis is confined to the study area, and in arid regions such as Northwest China, a 50 mm threshold may not effectively capture extreme precipitation events. For example, the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region Meteorological Service defines extreme rainfall as ranging from 24.1 to 48.0 mm.Quantifying changes in EP–PE is the focus of this study. Although population datasets with differing spatial resolutions may affect flood exposure estimates41, our analysis demonstrates strong consistency in EP–PE spatial patterns across multiple datasets, including KGP, WorldPop, GHS-POP, and GPWv4 (Supplementary Table 1 and Fig. 4). While minor variations exist, they do not alter the overall trends, particularly in identifying high-exposure urban areas (Supplementary Fig. 5). Despite this consistency, a major challenge remains: the lack of long-term, reliable population data. Current population projections are produced by different institutions, each applying distinct assumptions, influencing factors, and spatial-temporal resolutions42,43,44,45. While they generally project a pattern of population increase followed by a decline, notable differences are observed in the projected turning points, decline rates, and estimates at the provincial level. In some cases, the projected trends even point in opposite directions. Additionally, certain models oversimplify the description of internal population migration within China46,47. As a result, these limitations might contribute to considerable uncertainties in future population exposure projections.Under the dual pressures of climate change and rapid urbanization, Chinese cities are increasingly exposed to complex and compounded risks from extreme precipitation. As primary targets of the “expanding bull’s-eye effect”48, cities must require comprehensive strategies to mitigate disaster risks, including reducing exposure and addressing vulnerabilities to mitigate or control potential risks49. Our findings reveal that under high-GHG scenarios, both the EPF and EP–PE are projected to rise continuously. By contrast, low-GHG pathways could reduce EP–PE by up to 55.7% at most (Fig. 6b), underscoring the critical role of greenhouse gas mitigation in reducing future climate-related urban risks. China’s commitment to achieving carbon neutrality by 2060 offers a strategic policy window to simultaneously advance climate mitigation and strengthen disaster risk reduction in urban systems50.However, emission mitigation cannot fully address the compound pressures on urban systems. The impact of extreme precipitation is not solely disastrous: while it directly causes urban flooding and infrastructure damage, it also serves as a crucial source of groundwater recharge, especially in arid and semi-arid regions51,52,53. Existing studies have shown that large cities are more prone to groundwater depletion. Urban expansion exacerbates water stress in two ways: the expansion of impervious surfaces reduces natural infiltration, and the growing demand for water further exacerbates the imbalance. This is evident in the severe groundwater depletion observed in BTH-UA in the North China Plain and intermittent water stress in coastal cities like Jiangsu and Guangdong. On the other hand, economic development (GDP growth) can help ease groundwater pressure in urban areas by supporting investments in water infrastructure, expanding surface water irrigation, and implementing artificial recharge through canal and reservoir systems8,54. Notably, extreme precipitation can contribute up to 42% of groundwater recharge during wet periods55. However, under climate change, the increasing frequency of extreme precipitation events may negatively impact groundwater quality.Well-designed and maintained urban infrastructure, particularly stormwater drainage systems, can significantly reduce the vulnerability of cities to climate-induced flood risks56. Our analysis of drainage pipe density using 2006–2020 data from China Urban Construction Statistical Yearbook reveals significant regional disparities in flood risk management capacity across the four UAs (Supplementary Table 2). The YRD demonstrates superior flood resilience, evidenced by its higher drainage density. In contrast, the PRD, characterized by high population exposure and relatively low drainage density, shows widespread high-risk zones across its southern areas. The BTH and CC regions are predominantly in the moderate-risk category (Supplementary Figs. 6 and 7). Previous studies have shown that under high-emission scenarios, nearly 80% of cities in China are projected to face over 30% additional pressure on their drainage systems in the future. However, effective implementation of mitigation policies could significantly relieve this burden in more than half of these cities57.In terms of response strategies, cities should pursue resilience-oriented adaptation pathways. First, it is essential to continue prioritizing net-zero emissions and follow a sustainable development trajectory. At the engineering level, attention should be given to improving drainage systems by promoting sponge cities, low-impact development (LID), and the expansion of underground infrastructure58,59,60. Second, from a spatial governance perspective, population distribution should be guided toward small and medium-sized cities to curb the issues of overexpansion and hollowing-out in megacities18,61. Tailored urban development models should be adopted to improve land-use efficiency62,63. More importantly, enhancing urban resilience should be supported through legal and policy frameworks, incorporating climate adaptation standards into future urban planning64. Overall, relying solely on population exposure does not adequately capture the true adaptive capacity of social systems to extreme climate events. Future research should develop an integrated urban resilience assessment framework that combines natural and social dimensions, and further incorporates population exposure to climate-related hazards such as landslides triggered by extreme precipitation and flooding from rising river levels, thereby aligning risk identification with adaptive capacity building and supporting the transformation of cities toward more sustainable and resilient futures.MethodsClimate dataThe observational precipitation data used in this study are CN05.1, which is a daily gridded precipitation dataset with a spatial resolution of 0.25° × 0.25° and a time span from 1961 to 202065. To align with the time frame of the population data, this study focuses on the period from 1990 to 2020.The downscaled dataset NEX-GDDP-CMIP6, with a horizontal resolution of 0.25° × 0.25°, is employed for assessment of future extreme precipitation22. Following the guidelines of the IPCC report2, precipitation data from the historical run outputs for 1995–2014 are utilized to evaluate the simulation capability of the models and serve as the baseline period. The results of future projection for 2015–2100 are derived from experiments under three sets of SSPs: SSP1–2.6, SSP2–4.5, and SSP5–8.5. Among these, SSP2–4.5 represents a pathway maintaining the status quo without climate policies, SSP1–2.6 reflects a sustainable development scenario, and SSP5–8.5 corresponds to a fossil fuel-intensive future66,67. This study utilizes 27 models, which encompass all emission pathways, with detailed information on the specific models provided in Supplementary Table 3.Population dataThe Chinese Population Spatial Distribution Grid Dataset, released by the Institute of Geographic Sciences and Natural Resources Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, is used to analyze historical population distribution68. It is a high-resolution population dataset with a spatial resolution of 1 km and a temporal resolution of five years, including data for 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015, and 2020. Thus, the population data for 1990–1994 are replaced with the 1990 data, and this approach is applied similarly for other years. Besides, the 2020 data are used without substitution.The future annual population dataset for the period 2021–2100, released by a team from Tsinghua University43, incorporates various factors such as birth rates, death rates, migration, and education levels. It includes provincial-level forecasts that account for China’s recent fertility-promoting policies and the population caps in megacities. These forecasts are distributed across population grids with a horizontal resolution of 30 arc seconds. Validated against actual population trends from 2010 to 2020, the dataset offers reliable long-term projections through 210046.The nighttime light data used in this study is obtained from the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) carried by the Suomi National Polar-Orbiting Partnership (Suomi NPP) satellite, which was launched on October 28, 201169. Referred to as NPP-VIIRS, it has a spatial resolution of 500 m × 500 m and is commonly used to represent human economic activities70.Definition of EPF and EP-PEThe extreme precipitation threshold used in this study is defined by the China Meteorological Administration as a 24-h cumulative rainfall exceeding 50 mm71. The EPF is then calculated as the total number of extreme precipitation days. Population exposure refers to the locations where the regional population may be adversely affected, according to the definition provided by the IPCC report72. Hence, EP-PE represents the annual total EPF for each grid multiplied by the total population of the corresponding grid.Precipitation percentile mapping bias correction, and model optimizationGiven that climate models frequently exhibit deficiencies in capturing precipitation events exceeding 50 mm, a more efficient and streamlined calibration approach has been developed for model simulations, referred to as PPM. Unlike earlier investigations that directly corrected the simulated precipitation amounts, this study adjusts the threshold for identifying extreme precipitation. A comparison between the two methods shows that the precipitation bias after PPM correction is more concentrated. Except for the CC–UA, regions with bias absolute values less than or equal to 0.1 times per year for a larger proportion under PPM than under QM (Supplementary Fig. 2). Specifically, to identify a reasonable and consistent threshold for future projections, we use the 50 mm threshold to determine the corresponding percentile based on the observed long-term daily precipitation records from 1995 to 2014 (20 years × 365 days) for each observational grid point. This percentile is then applied to each model’s daily precipitation distribution to derive an absolute threshold for identifying extreme precipitation events in the simulations of each NEX–GDDP–CMIP6 model. The derived absolute thresholds are subsequently averaged across models to obtain a multi-model mean threshold, which is used as the standard for extreme precipitation.Next, the Taylor diagram, based on the pattern correlation coefficient (PCC), the spatial deviation (STD), and the spatial root mean square deviation (RMSD), is used to assess the models’ ability to simulate extreme precipitation73. We rank the models according to their PCC, STD, and RMSD values, reflecting their ability to reproduce the extreme precipitation in major UAs. To reduce the uncertainty of model simulations, models are added sequentially to MME from highest to lowest performance. By identifying the MME with the best performance from different numbers of included models, we determine and select the optimal-performing models, forming the op-MME.Data processing and statistical analysisDue to the discrepancies in spatial resolution between the population and precipitation datasets, we generate a grid that aligns with the resolution of the precipitation data, recalculating the population within this grid to ensure spatial and temporal consistency. In the analysis of long-term time series for EPF and EP-PE, this study employs the Theil–Sen estimator for linear regression74,75 and utilizes the Mann–Kendall non-parametric test to evaluate the statistical significance of trends, with a significance level of 0.0576,77.

items.title: Association of climate variables with pneumonia patterns in a tropical coastal province of thailand: a bayesian structural time series analysis
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 24 November 2025

Association of climate variables with pneumonia patterns in a tropical coastal province of thailand: a bayesian structural time series analysis
                    Kuafhum Koolong1 & Aroon La-up1

Scientific Reports

, Article number:  (2025)
            Cite this article
                    
                    
                    
                            We are providing an unedited version of this manuscript to give early access to its
                            findings. Before final publication, the manuscript will undergo further editing. Please note
                            there may be errors present which affect the content, and all legal disclaimers apply.

Subjects
        
            Climate-change impactsEnvironmental impactRisk factors

AbstractPneumonia is a significant global public health problem, and climatic factors play a crucial role in disease epidemic dynamics. However, there are limited studies on this relationship in tropical monsoon coastal climate regions. This study aimed to analyze the impact of climatic factors on pneumonia pattern in Satun Province, a southern coastal province of Thailand, using Bayesian Structural Time Series (BSTS) modeling. This ecological study utilized monthly time series data spanning 10 years (January 2015 – December 2024). Pneumonia case data (ICD-10: J12-J18) were collected from the National Disease Surveillance System, and monthly climatic data were obtained from Satun Province meteorological stations. The BSTS model was employed to decompose long-term trend components, seasonal patterns, and the simultaneous effects of multiple climatic variables, using spike-and-slab priors technique for Bayesian variable selection. The median number of pneumonia cases was 63.0 cases per month (IQR: 34.0-102.0). BSTS model analysis revealed that relative humidity was the most influential climatic predictor of pneumonia cases, demonstrating a 2-month lag effect (Posterior Inclusion Probability [PIP] = 0.284). A one standard deviation increase in relative humidity was associated with approximately 6.4% increase in cases. Other climatic variables such as temperature, precipitation, and wind speed were not identified as robust predictors in the final model. Additionally, distinct seasonal epidemic patterns were observed, with case peaking during October-November. Relative humidity is a factor associated with pneumonia epidemics in Satun Province, challenging traditional concepts that typically emphasize temperature as the primary factor in temperate regions. The discovery of this 2-month lag relationship is significant for developing public health early warning systems, enabling effective preparation of resources and proactive preventive measure planning.

Data availability
                  
                  The datasets used and/or analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

items.title: Perché decarbonizzare la piccola pesca artigianale nel Mediterraneo
items.description: Il 21 novembre, la Giornata Mondiale della Pesca ci ricorda che la pesca non riguarda solo il cibo: è persone, comunità, cultura e legame profondo con
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Ogni anno, il 21 novembre, la Giornata Mondiale della Pesca ci ricorda che la pesca non riguarda solo il cibo: è persone, comunità, cultura e un legame profondo con gli ecosistemi da cui dipende. Nel Mediterraneo, la piccola pesca artigianale riveste un ruolo fondamentale: fornisce gran parte del pesce destinato al consumo locale, preserva saperi tradizionali e sostiene economie costiere che esistono da generazioni. Ma oggi questo settore si trova a un bivio. Con la COP30 in corso, il mondo si interroga su come ogni settore possa contribuire alla lotta contro la crisi climatica. La piccola pesca artigianale deve essere parte di questo processo. Non solo perché le comunità costiere sono tra le più esposte agli impatti del cambiamento climatico, ma anche perché il settore stesso racchiude un potenziale ancora poco valorizzato in termini di decarbonizzazione e resilienza climatica. La piccola pesca di fronte alla sfida del cambiamento climatico I pescatori artigianali del Mediterraneo stanno già affrontando gli effetti del cambiamento climatico: mari più caldi, specie che migrano, crescente diffusione di specie invasive,erosione costiera ed eventi estremi. Questi fenomeni mettono a rischio la sicurezza alimentare, i redditi e il patrimonio culturale delle comunità. Eppure, il settore contribuisce anch’esso alle emissioni di gas serra. Attualmente, la piccola pesca è responsabile dell’8% delle emissioni totali di CO₂ del comparto pesca dell’UE, pari a circa 0,4 milioni di tonnellate all’anno. Un dato significativo, soprattutto considerando che gran parte della flotta costiera europea opera ancora con motori termici obsoleti e tecnologie a bassa efficienza, aggravando la dipendenza dai combustibili fossili e riducendo la competitività economica. Decarbonizzare: una necessità, ma anche un’opportunità Ridurre le emissioni della piccola pesca non è solamente una necessità ambientale: è una scelta strategica indispensabile per proteggere il futuro stesso della pesca. Questo significa: Ridurre i costi operativi grazie a un minor consumo di carburante.Migliorare la competitività sul mercato, dove la sostenibilità è sempre più richiesta.Contribuire alla sicurezza alimentare garantendo catture più sostenibili e responsabili.Sbloccare finanziamenti verdi ed incentivi per l’adozione di tecnologie pulite. In sintesi, decarbonizzare la piccola pesca rappresenta un’opportunità strategica per allineare sostenibilità ambientale e redditività economica. Possibili percorsi di cambiamento Cosa significa, concretamente, decarbonizzare questo settore? Alcune strade includono: Efficienza energetica: motori più efficienti, imbarcazioni ibride o elettriche;Pratiche post-raccolta sostenibili: l’uso di energia rinnovabile nella lavorazione e conservazione del pescato riduce sprechi e migliora la qualità;Strumenti digitali per l’efficienza: applicazioni per pianificare le uscite, ottimizzare i percorsi e ridurre consumi inutili;Diversificazione e valorizzazione: integrare la pesca con attività di turismo sostenibile o filiere locali a basso impatto. Queste soluzioni devono essere adattate ai contesti locali,  con il coinvolgimento diretto delle comunità e un accesso facilitato a tecnologie e finanziamenti. Un esempio concreto è il progetto pilota che WWF Italia sta portando avanti nelle marinerie di Chioggia e Caorle (Veneto), in collaborazione con il mondo della ricerca e diverse aziende specializzate. Qui si stanno sperimentando tecnologie innovative per ridurre le emissioni delle imbarcazioni artigianali, combinando vernici ecologiche, che non rilasciano sostanze tossiche in acqua e sostituiscono le tradizionali antivegetative, con sistemi a ultrasuoni alimentati da energia solare per limitare il biofouling. In questo modo si mantiene lo scafo pulito, si migliora l’efficienza delle barche e si riduce il consumo di carburante, generando benefici sia ambientali che economici per i pescatori coinvolti. Un piccolo ma concreto passo verso una pesca a basse emissioni, replicabile in altri contesti italiani e del Mediterraneo. Un appello per la COP30 La Giornata Mondiale della Pesca e la COP30 ci ricordano che le soluzioni basate sulla natura e l’azione comunitaria devono essere al centro delle strategie climatiche. I pescatori artigianali possono diventare protagonisti della transizione ecologica e innovatori della transizione verso un futuro a basse emissioni. Ma non possono farcela da soli. Governi, istituzioni finanziarie, università e settore privato devono creare condizioni favorevoli: politiche che incentivino pratiche a basso impatto, investimenti in tecnologie pulite e accesso al finanziamento climatico per piccole imprese. In questo World Fisheries Day, il messaggio è chiaro: supportare la piccola pesca artigianale nella transizione a basse emissioni non è solo un dovere ambientale. È un atto di giustizia climatica, equità e sostenibilità per le comunità costiere del Mediterraneo. Mediterranean Marine Initiative La Mediterranean Marine Initiative è un programma di trasformazione su scala regionale basato sullo sforzo coordinato degli uffici del WWF nel Mediterraneo. Rafforza la capacità del WWF di portare avanti la conservazione marina nel Mediterraneo costruendo nuove alleanze e creando nuove soluzioni per le sfide del bacino. Scopri di più Transforming small scale fisheries Collaboriamo con le comunità costiere per migliorare la gestione delle risorse ittiche al fine di ripristinare gli stock ittici, garantendo al contempo la salvaguardia dell’ecosistema marino e la sussistenza delle comunità stesse. Rafforziamo le relazioni tra pescatori, autorità locali e ricercatori, rendendole più stabili e durature nel lungo termine. Scopri di più

items.title: Bracconaggio, in crescita i crimini di natura
items.description:
+52% di uccelli protetti uccisi in Lombardia rispetto al 2024. La conferenza stampa del WWF a Milano: la politica ha evidenti responsabilità
The post
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie +52% di uccelli protetti uccisi in Lombardia rispetto al 2024 Il bracconaggio è in crescita, nonostante la crescente sensibilità ambientale. I dati parlano da soli: 1.043 esemplari di uccelli protetti morti conferiti al CRAS WWF di Valpredina nel 2025, contro i 685 del 2024, con un incremento del +52,26% e si prevede che questi numeri aumentino ancora considerato che la stagione venatoria non è conclusa. Numeri relativi alle sole province di Brescia e Bergamo che si prevede aumentino ancora, considerato che la stagione venatoria non è conclusa, e che confermano la gravità di un fenomeno criminale sempre più organizzato. A crescere sono in particolare le uccisioni di piccoli uccelli protetti come il pettirosso. A questi numeri si aggiungono le migliaia di uccelli sequestrati dalle forze di polizia perché detenute illegalmente, spesso per essere usate come “richiami vivi”, come emerge anche dai dati pubblicati dai Carabinieri forestali (Operazione Pettirosso condotta dalla Sezione Operativa Antibracconaggio, SOARDA). Guardie WWF Brescia La conferenza stampa del WWF a Milano L’allarme WWF è stato lanciato oggi in  occasione di una conferenza stampa tenutasi presso il Consiglio Regionale della Lombardia. Dietro il bracconaggio non ci sono più solo singoli individui, ma vere e proprie organizzazioni criminali che hanno capito che investire in questo settore significa fare affari d’oro rischiando pochissimo. La sottovalutazione della gravità del fenomeno – che danneggia la biodiversità, la salute umana e l’economia legale – rende inefficaci gli strumenti di prevenzione e repressione: controlli sul territorio, indagini, processi e sanzioni. In questo senso il ruolo della politica è fondamentale: deve tradurre la sensibilità dell’opinione pubblica e le evidenze di un crimine in crescita, non cedere alle pressioni di chi chiede di ridurre i controlli e favorire concessioni alle lobby venatorie, ma dimostrare senso di responsabilità nella tutela degli interessi comuni e dei principi sanciti dall’articolo 9 della Costituzione. Al contrario molte regioni hanno via via demolito la tutela della fauna selvatica. La Lombardia, ad esempio ha modificato la legge sulla caccia ben 28 volte negli ultimi 10 anni e questa pericolosa tendenza oggi è registrata anche a livello nazionale.Domenico Aiello, responsabile Tutela giuridica della natura del WWF Italia L’esempio negativo della Lombardia La Lombardia è stata indicata come esempio negativo: negli ultimi anni, scelte legislative e amministrative hanno indebolito il sistema dei controlli e introdotto misure che vanno sulla strada opposta, da ultima, la caccia in deroga a fringuello e storno, sospesa solo grazie al ricorso del WWF e di altre associazioni accolto dal Consiglio di Stato. “Questi atti non solo non contrastano il bracconaggio, ma lo favoriscono”, ha sottolineato Mario Attalla, coordinatore WWF Lombardia. Dati drammatici dal Cras di Valpredina Matteo Mauri, responsabile del CRAS WWF Valpredina, ha illustrato i dati drammatici sugli animali recuperati: centinaia di uccelli protetti morti e feriti, vittime di trappole e armi da fuoco, tra cui specie rare come lo smeriglio, il picchio nero, l’ibis eremita. Il 91% degli animali ricoverati al CRAS con ferita d’arma da fuoco viene ritrovato durante la stagione venatoria. CRAS WWF Valpredina Antonio Delle Monache, responsabile della vigilanza volontaria WWF della Lombardia, ha rendicontato sull’attività di controllo effettuata dalle guardie WWF durante la stagione venatoria in corso a supporto delle autorità pubbliche che ha consentito di denunciare 42 persone e sequestrare 214 uccelli protetti uccisi illegalmente oltre a numerose trappole e sistemi di cattura illegali. Gianfelice Facchetti, scrittore e giornalista, ha poi richiamato l’urgenza di una svolta culturale per fermare questa deriva.Alla conferenza hanno partecipato anche rappresentanti istituzionali impegnati sul tema: On. Eleonora Evi (PD), i consiglieri regionali Simone Negri (PD), Paola Pollini (M5S), Michela Palestra (Patto Civico) e Onorio Rosati (AVS) che hanno espresso preoccupazione per la situazione e la volontà di rafforzare le politiche di tutela. La mobilitazione del WWF contro il DDL “Caccia Selvaggia” Il WWF ha inoltre rilanciato la mobilitazione contro il DDL “Caccia Selvaggia” in discussione al Senato, che rischia di smantellare le tutele per la fauna e rendere ancora più difficile il contrasto agli illeciti. La petizione #StopCacciaSelvaggia ha superato le 100.000 firme, segnale forte della volontà dei cittadini di difendere la natura. Stop caccia selvaggia Chiedi al Governo di non consegnare la fauna ai cacciatori Firma 5 Dicembre 2024 Operazione Pettirosso, i carabinieri contro il bracconaggio Le Prealpi lombardo-venete, una delle aree italiane più colpite dal bracconaggio, sono state ancora una volta il teatro dell’operazione “Pettirosso Lucio Biancatelli 10 Novembre 2020 Bracconaggio, conclusa l'operazione Pettirosso All’operazione hanno collaborato anche le Guardie volontarie del WWF Si è conclusa l’Operazione antibracconaggio dei Carabinieri Forestali denominata “Pettirosso”, coordinata dal Reparto operativo SOARDA (Sezione Operativa Antibracconaggio e Reati in Danno agli Animali) del Raggruppamento Carabinieri CITES con i gruppi Carabinieri Forestali di…
